bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, November 14, 1944

div1.p: Kean criticizes an article that claims Gorgas was ahead of his time when, in fact, he was slow to react to Reed's conclusions.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, November 14, 1944
div1.opener:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
Nov. 14/44
My dear Col Hench
div1.p:
Cornelia has brought me this
clipping and asked me to put it
in an envelope and mail it to you.
I dont think she wants to convert you
to Mr. Schmidt's idea but she thinks
that any allusion to yellow fever
will interest you. You and I who know
how slow Gorgas was to accept Reed's
demonstration (it took six months for
the fomites experiments to soak in)
do not think he was “ahead of his time”.
I think he was pushed ashore by the
crest of the first big wave. But he
made a fine apostle after he saw the
vision and was as Paul preaching
to the gentiles. But tho. Captain
Schmidt did not pick the best
example to prove his cause I am
inclined to think he is on the right
track. You dont have to answer this
though I am always glad to have
a line from you
